title: FirstFT: Big Tech profits surge to new heights
text:
Big Tech profits have surged to unexpected heights even as the global economy starts to emerge from the coronavirus pandemic that gave a boost to the biggest technology companies last year.

Apple, Microsoft and Alphabet all reported revenues and earnings above already optimistic expectations, making tech groups among the biggest beneficiaries of this year's gradual recovery, just as they proved to be one of the most resilient sectors during the Covid-19 downturn.

The three US tech groups brought in combined after-tax profits of almost $5bn a week during the latest quarter. At $56.8bn, the total was almost double the year before and 30 per cent more than Wall Street had predicted.

Jim Tierney, a portfolio manager at AllianceBernstein, described the results as “absolutely stunning”.

“I think the takeaway is, all the digital habits that we picked up over the past 12 months, they're going to stick with us when we come out of this.”

Five more stories in the news

1. Anti-Trump Republicans slam party for trivialising Capitol attack After months of wrangling between Nancy Pelosi and Kevin McCarthy the hearings into the January 6 assault by a pro-Trump mob on the US Capitol began yesterday. In an emotional day of testimony, Adam Kinzinger, a Republican member of the House of Representatives from Illinois, held back tears as he called his party's approach to the hearings “toxic”.

2. Horizon Kinetics bets on property and cypto The $7bn contrarian investment firm, one of the year's best-performing US fund managers, is betting on property and cryptocurrencies to protect its investors against rising inflation. “There is no turning back after the pandemic and globally there is a debt problem and it means either default or currency debasement,” co-founder Peter Doyle tells the Financial Times.

3. Chinese tech sell-off slows A sharp sell-off in Chinese stocks slowed today as investors caught their breath after Beijing's crackdown on education and technology companies prompted an epic rout this week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng fell as much as 1 per cent, taking the index 20 per cent lower from its February high and putting it on the cusp of a bear market

  • Go deeper: Here's why Xi Jinping is cracking down on China's education sector.

4. US defence chief questions UK pivot to Asia Lloyd Austin said Britain might be more helpful as an ally if it did not focus on Asia, highlighting US concerns that forays by European allies into the Indo-Pacific could weaken their defences closer to home.

5. Spyware group NSO's owner stripped of control of €1bn fund Investors in private equity group Novalpina Capital's €1bn fund voted this month to seize control after a tense three-hour video call, a dramatic intervention that left ownership of the Israeli company behind spying software Pegasus hanging in the balance.

Tokyo Olympics round-up

  • Four-time Olympic gold medallist Simone Biles withdrew from today's women's all-around gymnastics final, a day after pulling out of the women's gymnastics team final. USA Gymnastics said Biles would be evaluated daily to determine if she would participate in the four individual events next week.

  • There was better news for the host nation a day after tennis star Naomi Osaka crashed out of the Games. Yui Ohashi won her second gold medal after beating American Alex Walsh in the 200-metre individual medley — the first time a Japanese female swimmer has won two golds at the Olympics. Nineteen-year-old Tomoru Honda clinched a silver in the men's 200-metre butterfly.

  • Australian swimmer Ariarne Titmus took her second straight gold medal and set a new Olympic record in the women's 200-metre freestyle.

  • Italo Ferreira of Brazil won the first-ever surfing gold medal. American Carissa Moore won the women's gold.

Add ‘Tokyo Olympics' to myFT for all our coverage from the Games, and don't miss our “alternative medals table”.

The day ahead

Fed monetary policy decision The Federal Reserve concludes a two-day rate-setting meeting as investors seek clues on the timing of the US central bank's tapering of its bond purchases. The decision has been complicated by the recent jump in US coronavirus cases.

Earnings Facebook is expected to become the latest big tech group to report higher earnings on the back of a surge in demand for its services from locked-down consumers during the pandemic.

  • Also reporting: Pfizer, Boeing, Ford, McDonald's, Qualcomm, PayPal and Spotify.

Robinhood IPO The retail brokerage app is expected to price its shares after the market closes today. An unusually large amount of shares is being set aside for retail investors, leaving money managers braced for volatility when the shares start trading tomorrow.

Peru's new president Pedro Castillo will be sworn in on Peru's 200th anniversary of independence. The leftwing president's rise to power marks the decline of the Fujimori dynasty, which has loomed large over Peruvian politics for more than three decades.

Coronavirus digest

  • US health officials recommended vaccinated people in areas with “substantial and high transmission” wear masks indoors, reversing previous guidance.

  • Developing economies' limited access to vaccines threatens to hinder the global economic recovery from the pandemic, the IMF has warned.

  • Downing Street is expected to approve reopening England to double-vaccinated tourists from the EU and the US today as falling case numbers offered Britons hope.

The global race to vaccinate is having a use beyond the medical: it is delineating two populisms, writes Janan Ganesh. Sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter and get the latest on our blog.

What else we're reading

Legal talent wars “Golden handcuffs”, sign-on bonuses of up to $100,000 and special spring payments are all being used by US law firms to lure and retain junior and mid-career lawyers amid a period of frenzied corporate dealmaking. “Everyone is pulling out the stops,” says a recruiter to the legal industry.

Global Britain or hostile environment? Critics say the enforcement of post-Brexit immigration rules are harsh and inflexible, endangering the UK's “global” aspirations and leaving sectors from meat-processing to haulage short of workers since the end of free movement.

Have we entered a new phase of climate change? A Canadian village records heat of 49.6C, floodwaters tear through German towns like a tsunami and terrified Chinese subway passengers stand in chest-high water. Could we be entering a new period of non-linear climate change? For years scientists have predicted a smooth rise in temperatures but that view is beginning to change, writes Pilita Clark.

How SoftBank's Greensill dalliance ended in disaster After coming unstuck on WeWork, the Japanese group pulled out all the stops to save its next investment. But rather than distancing itself from Greensill when it learnt of its shaky foundations, SoftBank got closer. Its strategy failed.
